website_summaries.verdict: An ideal gardening companion for planting bulbs, bedding plants, and seedlings, with holes up to 28 inches deep.
pros: Attaches easily to most electric and cordless drills
Designed to greatly speed up your planting time in the garden
Quick and efficient with a well-made, heavy-duty design

customer_reviews.title: Cheap design, will not work under any realistic load
customer_reviews.text: Very poor and cheap design. That's my opinion at least. The fact is that the spiral is held on by 3 small tack welds. Worst of all, the end of the shaft is a CIRCLE, not a hexagon. As soon as it felt any tension the chuck slipped and stripped the cheap coating. Very cheap, would not recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Joe

customer_reviews.title: Works great for intended purpose. NOT intended to penetrate thick clay soil or rock hard, bone dry dirt.
customer_reviews.text: Planted 500 bulbs in 6 hours thanks to this auger. Worked great with cheap power drill. However, my soil was loose because I’d built up the bed and slightly wet due to recent light rain. When I hit a buried tree root, the bit spun in my drill chuck, but that’s OK: the last thing I want is to have the drill ripped out of my hands. On my drill, I could set the clutch so it released when I hit a root but the auger would pull the soil out up to 8 inches. Read the instructions, and pull the auger up every couple of inches to clear the soil from the hole.
customer_reviews.author: John W. Michael

customer_reviews.title: Does the job
customer_reviews.text: It works best when you move the drill up and down as you drill the hole. This allows grass and soil to be moved out of the hole. Trying to drill straight through without moving up and down can cause the drill to bog down. I was satisfied with this product, especially after I learned the best way to use it.
customer_reviews.author: Larry

customer_reviews.title: Perfect width and length for gardening.
customer_reviews.text: This soil auger is just the perfect width and length for boring holes in my garden for aeration and fertilization. I spread compost on the area where I want to enrich the soil and then, using a hand drill, I bore holes into the ground. This mixes the compost into the existing soil and provides aeration of the soil too. It works best to drill the holes very slowly, in case you hit roots, and to put the drill in reverse each time you bring the auger bit back up and out of the hole. I am very pleased with the quality of the metal auger and by how well it works for my purpose.
customer_reviews.author: Flamingo Girl

customer_reviews.title: Try it
customer_reviews.text: This is great. I use it with a craftsman 19.2v cordless 3/8 drill. What used to take most of a day now takes less than 2 hours! Great for removing weeds, sticker weeds, flower boxes, probably could even drill post holes for a 4x4 post. (I'll try that next). I see some negative reviews, however I dont agree with them. Everyone has different experiences. I'd easily buy again, but only the 30" or longer ones as bending over gets harder as you get older. Highly recommend this one!
customer_reviews.author: R. King

customer_reviews.title: Works, just use it carefully...
customer_reviews.text: I bought this to drill a tunnel under a brick walkway (4 ft) for an electrical conduit. I did not want to collapse the brick work using water, so I used this small diameter auger carefully drilling from both sides and slipping the pvc through. The auger is spot welded in several areas to the shaft so, could probably break if forced (it could probably be fixed if you know someone with a welder) . I went through a relatively hard clay/sand mixture taking care to exert minimal pressure and pulling the auger out completely many times to clear the debris and small stones. It worked perfectly. Be aware, also, it gets hot from the friction.
customer_reviews.author: Charles

customer_reviews.title: Failed Drilling First Hole
customer_reviews.text: I tried using this auger to aerate compacted soil around a tree. After a couple minutes the shaft sheared at the drill chuck. Lifetime guarantee but such a short life! Returning.
customer_reviews.author: Big Pa

customer_reviews.title: Dug through clay, mulch, 10-12” deep x9 holes no problems
customer_reviews.text: I drilled 9 holes through mulch, dirt and some clay without it bending or breaking. The end where it connects to the drill has 3 flat spots for you drill to catch so not sure why folks saying it is completely smooth. Only thing I wish was if the blades continued a bit higher to push dirt out of the hole. After 8-10” had to drill some and quickly pull out to remove soil/clay. Definitely did the job, was nervous with the hard soil I dug in. Still pretty darn straight.
customer_reviews.author: Tom

customer_reviews.title: Priceless
customer_reviews.text: Parked down on the beach, grabbed my bucket, Sport Brella XL and my radio. Walked down closer to the water and a kid walked up to me with a screw gun with a bit on the end of it and asked me if he could help me set up my umbrella. Now I can appreciate that these kids work for tax free tips (and I'm sure they do very well). But you should have seen his face when I lifted the towel off my bucket and revealed a screw gun with an 18" bit on it. PRICELESS!!!!!
customer_reviews.author: Slow-N- Low

customer_reviews.title: Pretty sturdy, got job done in hard clay soil
customer_reviews.text: The cylindrical shank seems sacrificial. You can see in the photo how it wore down after boring holes in pretty hard clay soil. I make these holes for tree fertilizer spikes- much easier than trying to hammer them in which is impossible. So anyway with my 1/2” electric drill this was enough of a beast. The welds held up great and though the leading flute dulled / wore out a bit a file can bring it back. I had to cut an inch or so off the shank with a hacksaw when I was done. No tool put to demanding use is going to last forever; I’m getting my money’s worth.
customer_reviews.author: Tripp Knightly

customer_reviews.title: Looking at my work I thought that looks like.. well so I place a file against ...
customer_reviews.text: yes it has a round shaft for the chuck which will allow it to spin in hard dirt, I have hard dirt so not having a grinder but a set of files I clamped it in a vice and filed flats. Looking at my work I thought that looks like .. well so I place a file against the bench and the handle into my belt line, and moved the shaft down the file making a good flat on 4 sides. In fact it worked so well that I had to use channel locks to release my hand chuck. Maybe it was the rock garden I uncovered with this tool. I does work well with minor modifications
customer_reviews.author: Theodore C Forster

customer_reviews.title: ... to make holes for our beach umbrella ~ works wonderfully!
customer_reviews.text: We bought this specifically to use with a drill to make holes for our beach umbrella ~ works wonderfully!
customer_reviews.author: Mimi D

customer_reviews.title: I read all the negatives..... ...
customer_reviews.text: I read all the negatives.....but got it anyway. AND I WILL NEVER DOUBT reviews AGAIN. THIS is a PIECE OF #$%^. Will not stay locked in drill .....gets stuck in ground and is not deep enough to plant a seed. I LITERALLY threw this in the trash today. IN THE TRASH. Pay for one that WORKS.
customer_reviews.author: TexasT

customer_reviews.title: I bought this to use with a pest control mechanism ...
customer_reviews.text: I bought this to use with a pest control mechanism called a Gopher Hawk, which requires the user to make a hole in the ground to accommodate the trap. This works perfectly, it makes using the trap much easier. I also picked up the cheapest cordless drill Harbor Freight sells ($15) to avoid getting dirt in my Makita -- the combination is ideal for this purpose. At some point I may try to free-hand grind the end of the shaft to 1/4" hex, so I can use an extension to make it a few inches longer, but it certainly serves me well as it.
customer_reviews.author: Mark McGinty

customer_reviews.title: Worth it
customer_reviews.text: I use this to drill holes in the garden for bulbs. I am happy to say it's worth getting the drill out because it's definitely easier to place bulbs than digging in between perennials with my shovel. The auger and drill get a little bit dirty but they are easy enough to clean. The only thing I'd mention is that after getting this, I noticed some gardeners have a much longer one, which saves them from bending down. I sort of wish I had one of the long ones... but I'm not sure it would go well with my rather small drill. So maybe I'm better off with this one, which works quite well with my battery powered drill.
customer_reviews.author: Rachel

customer_reviews.title: Does exactly what it was meant to do
customer_reviews.text: Does exactly what it was meant to do. Very handy for planting bulbs. I purchased this to plant a few dozen seedling trees. Using this auger and a rechargeable drill made the job go very fast. Worth mentioning; this auger is very small take this into consideration when ordering. get the right size for whatever job you have in mind. It was just right for my use. A larger one may be useful for a wider range of uses.
customer_reviews.author: Everyday guy

customer_reviews.title: Great for weeding little trees out of flower garden!
customer_reviews.text: I have 100s of little trees (1-2” tall) growing in my flower garden! Not anymore, this auger worked great to weed these out. The shaft was notched to allow the drill chuck to get a good grip. Appears very well made. Registered for lifetime warranty on Yard Butler’s website. Only negative was price, Yard Butler sells this item for 21.99 + shipping on their website. I expected a better deal from Amazon but I did get free shipping. Very happy with product.
customer_reviews.author: Michael Olson

customer_reviews.title: So far so good
customer_reviews.text: Worked great to drill a few holes for landscape lights. This thing is not heavy duty but you will be fine if you set the clutch on your drill to avoid damage! Once the clutch slips reverse to unstick the auger. If you are careful you won't ruin it. If you have a welder you could add a few more weld points to make it stronger but I don't think I'll need to do that. Just don't abuse it and remember to set your clutch and you should be ok.
customer_reviews.author: Stephen Martins

customer_reviews.title: Save time planting!
customer_reviews.text: This is a life saver! When my wife beings home what seems like a pallet of those 6-pack trays of flowers from the stores, my back starts to ache before I even start. This easily makes planting 10 times faster. Be careful if you have Rocky or clay-like soil as we do in Arkansas. The auger may grip and either twist hard in your hand or drive into the ground like a screw. Just don't rev up the drill to full power and you'll be good. Totally worth it!
customer_reviews.author: Brady Delperdang

customer_reviews.title: Real time-saver for taking soil samples
customer_reviews.text: I have been using a soil tube for several years to take annual soil samples around the farm (about 100 samples/year). During dry weather the soil tube could not easily penetrate deep enough for a proper sample. This auger was terrific at boring a 6-8 inch deep hole and extracting a soil sample. Cut my total time for sample collection in half. Very handy to have around. Worked well with a battery powered drill. Did not slip in the chuck at all.
customer_reviews.author: Appreciates a Good Product

customer_reviews.title: Works!
customer_reviews.text: After reading all the reviews, I purchased this and tried to flatten the end a little to keep it from spinning in the drill. I don't have whatever tool everyone else has so it doesn't work as perfectly as they say, but it does keep it in the drill for a decent amount of time before it falls out. It works much better on looser soil but still worked relatively well in my clay soil. It 100% made planting all my bulbs and flats of plants easier and I recommend it for sure.
customer_reviews.author: A. ReneeTop Contributor: Baby

customer_reviews.title: Not worth it
customer_reviews.text: I paid $15.84 for a Amazon warehouse deal. It is not worth more than $10. 1. The steel is not tempered, I don't expect an earth digging equipment of any sorts to be not tempered, it bents very easily. Even a little bent on it will have a bad experience with a rotating drill. 2. The drill end is not hexagonal, for easy attachment to the drill. 3. The earth digging end is not aggressive enough to dig into dry soil. Overall, its not a good product to suggest. Update after couple of holes: I raised to 3 star, it works. I mean, you can make your job done.
customer_reviews.author: Sarthak Nayak

customer_reviews.title: I like it but one caution.....
customer_reviews.text: Does what it is suppose to do well. It is sturdy. Now for the warning....watch how you are holding your drill, if it gets stuck on a rock or a root the drill is going to spin with quite a bit of force.. Depending on how you hold the drill it could twist your hand and potentially force your finger to pull the drill trigger harder.. Go slow, and take your time, a medium speed is better than wide open.
customer_reviews.author: James Cosby

customer_reviews.title: It makes holes easily
customer_reviews.text: This did a much better job digging in my hard Arizona dirt than I expected. Using a corded drill it worked almost too well and threw rocks and dirt everywhere. The only problem I've had is the finish on the shaft didn't let the drill chuck hold on well enough and it ended up spinning in the chuck until the finish was worn off. It seems like it will be able to grip it now that it's bare metal but would be nice if it came with a better surface on the end.
customer_reviews.author: Brian

customer_reviews.title: It is amazing, and I can zip along digging a number ...
customer_reviews.text: Every once in a while you buy a tool and think "Why didn't I buy this 20 years ago?" That is the case with this tool. After struggling for years to dig holes deep enough to properly plant flower bulbs, using various devices, I decided to give this a shot. It is amazing, and I can zip along digging a number of holes in seconds that probably used to take an hour or more. One of the best tools that I have ever purchased!
customer_reviews.author: jk7276

customer_reviews.title: It Digs!
customer_reviews.text: This is an awesome tool. I have been using it to pull weeds. I wish my drill was larger. First it grabs all the weeds. (be careful not to grab your plants) then I clean it off and go back and dig holes, simply to kill the roots. And when I want to plant bulbs I will use it for the holes. This is my first and only roto digger so I have no comparisons.
customer_reviews.author: macreato

customer_reviews.title: why not have a hexagon shaped shaft like all drill bits
customer_reviews.text: Tension will slip and strip with mininal tension. My drill cannot grip the circular shaft! If this is designed to be use with a drill, why not have a hexagon shaped shaft like all drill bits... I do not recommend this and will return it.
customer_reviews.author: CPT Dropshot

customer_reviews.title: drills holes good
customer_reviews.text: I use this to drill 2 ft deep holes in the dirt near the bases of stumps so that I can fit a 2" PVC pipe full of Tannerite like reactive target material, which is perfect for making a large space under the stump to then put even more Tannerite. Its a multi step process to blow up stumps, but i definitely couldn't do it without one of these augers. I took one star away only because the shaft strips and slips easily in the drill chuck because it is round, I may use my welding machine and forge to make a crude hex shaft end so that my drill grips it better.
customer_reviews.author: Bobby Blue

customer_reviews.title: Great product that REALLY WORKS!
customer_reviews.text: Got this item yesterday and followed the advice of another reviewer and first used my Dremel tool to flatten two spots on the otherwise round (and rather slick) shaft. Worked like a charm. I am not sure what kind of soil I used it in, but this thing REALLY WORKS! I forgot to slow down, and it was buried half way up the shaft before I could stop it. I reversed out and then used the method of taking it in and out to removed the dirt that is loosened by the auger. Worked great. I highly recommend this auger. Now I am looking for more projects on which to use it, because it is fun to use.
customer_reviews.author: David in Delray

customer_reviews.title: Makes planting a lot easier. Or mixing up a compost bin.
customer_reviews.text: This tool is perfect for fast holes for planting. Or to use to turnover compost.(which is my main use) IF you're expecting this to cut through roots, not going to happen. Buy a gas post hole digger, and hang on! This was well worth the price, and will last for a long time. Just remember, this is not a drill bit. This has made gardening a whole lot easier. I was NOT compensated for this review.
customer_reviews.author: Patrick Casey    S.W. Florida

customer_reviews.title: Use to install tree fertilizer spikes!
customer_reviews.text: I used to get on my knees and dig and hammer and break tree spikes, usually about 80 each year! Now, i drill and drop the spike in just below the surface, kick the dirt in, step on it and move on. No kneeling or bending involved!! Plus the time I save! Thank you! Note: drill gently and be ready to hit a root or a rock. Immediately stop! start a new hole
customer_reviews.author: KitKat

customer_reviews.title: Not tough enough for compacted clay soil
customer_reviews.text: If you have a good 1/2" chuck drill, you'll be able to use this easily, until it breaks... After a dozen holes or so, the shaft became bent making it hard to control. Also, it slips free from the drill chuck and spins occasionally because it has a round shaft. Next time, I'll have the sense to spend money on one of the better products out there like this. The Tanaka 745201 (also listed by Amazon) seems like it might actually be good quality. And, always use the second handle when using a big drill with something like this, you could injure yourself when it gets stuck otherwise!
customer_reviews.author: Nom, nom, nom de plume

customer_reviews.title: OK but that's all
customer_reviews.text: It was as described. Used an old corded drill, which got really hot but the chuck held. Backing it up constantly like others advised, it would still get stuck and the most I could drill down through mostly hard clay soil was to the top of the screw part, if that far. Through grass, it was impossible to get even that far. So it sort of did what I needed but not what I wanted.
customer_reviews.author: Holy Cow!

customer_reviews.title: The end probably needs to be ground down on a ...
customer_reviews.text: The end probably needs to be ground down on a side or two to help it lock into the chuck. I had it slip on me a couple times. At one point, I got it stuck in my hard soil and needed to use vice grips to 'unscrew it". The holes that I drilled out for some annual flowers are flourishing compared to the rest of them .Worked very well and made drop in holes.
customer_reviews.author: Andrew M

customer_reviews.title: Wow this is one of the more useful implements especially when i have to work with hard ...
customer_reviews.text: Wow this is one of the more useful implements especially when i have to work with hard soil. Just attach it to a cordless drill. I use it for temporary fences and putting in small posts or irrigation, cold frames, posts for trellising or support stakes. Great for aerating low spots that collect water so it drains faster.
customer_reviews.author: mrk

customer_reviews.title: Cheap drill bit
customer_reviews.text: I had to drill holes for a temporary little league baseball fence. This bit lasted for 18 holes, half the length of the fence. The fins wore right off. This is a cheap drill bit for very very light light dirt drilling. Spend more money for a heavier duty drill bit..... not this one
customer_reviews.author: Michelle

customer_reviews.title: Works well . . . with a minor modification.
customer_reviews.text: Works well enough. However, I filed 3-flats on the shaft to stop the thing slipping in the drill chuck. I'm pretty strong, but even tightening it hard, the round shaft would slip after a few holes. Now it's fine. The manufacturer might think of adding that extra process to make it very good. Useful hole by which to hang it up too.
customer_reviews.author: Black Cat 9 Lives

customer_reviews.title: A great time saver
customer_reviews.text: WOW! What a time saver. After battling the old planting method with a trowel, I decided to order this auger. After trying my cordless drill with a keyless chuck, it didn't work. The auger spun in the chuck. So, as others suggested, I filed two flat sides on the shaft. Also, I used my corded drill with a key chuck. PERFECT! With the key, I was able to get a tight fit. Probably the flat sides helped. Once I had all the preliminaries out of the way, I drilled 10 holes for planting bulbs in about 15 minutes. Only reason for not giving 5 stars is the shaft that should come with two or three flat sides.
customer_reviews.author: Molyneux

customer_reviews.title: Worked Well from the Very Beginning
customer_reviews.text: I helped soften hard, hard dirt for my wife who was planting Black Eyed Susan flowers. With a portable drill I was able to quickly drill six to seven holes in an area and dig out the loose dirt, then drill more holes in the bottom of that. Clearing the dirt out again gave me a perfect diameter hole at the correct depth. Then, zip, we planted the flowers. Works great. I'm going to use it to drill holes near trees where there is sod so water can sink in without running off.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Terrific!
customer_reviews.text: What a difference! I was digging narrow 8-inch deep holes by hand to bury some lawn sprinklers. It took forever. Using this auger, though, each hole took about a minute! Very pleased! I did learn that when the cutting edge encountered a root I backed out slightly and let it slice through it slowly, but it worked each time like a charm.
customer_reviews.author: Jeff Schaffer

customer_reviews.title: Use this to turn compost pile
customer_reviews.text: This makes turning a compost pile easy. Seriously attached to my 20v dewaltdriver and it takes less then 2 minutes and zero strength. I used to avoid turning the pile as it was backbreaking work. My pile is actually heated up and shrinking into compost not just overflowing the bin .
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Spins in chuck
customer_reviews.text: Unfortunately this auger does not have flat spots on the shaft like a regular drill bit does. There’s nothing for the drill chuck to grab on to when drilling into the ground so when you encounter hard earth or a rock the bit stops spinning with the drill and loosens the chuck. The bit seems very sturdy other than that.
customer_reviews.author: Ben

customer_reviews.title: Good quality. Works great for bulbs.
customer_reviews.text: I think this worked really well. I probably could have bought one with larger diameter as my bulbs were large. This was still very useful and made planting 50 bulbs not bad at all. Deep enough that the rabbits/ squirrels haven't gotten to them yet.
customer_reviews.author: Seth Steele

customer_reviews.title: Pretty good for making holes for fruit trees.
customer_reviews.text: I wanted to make some deep holes next to fruit trees to deliver nutrients and water deep in the soil. This make the job pretty easy, like 2 min job. You have to keep moving up and down to clear the new dirt it has dug up otherwise it will get stuck.
customer_reviews.author: Nadar

customer_reviews.title: Auger bit
customer_reviews.text: The auger bit is find for my use. I needed to plant blubs around some trees. It was better than trying to dig with a spade. The ground is hard and some top roots. The best way to use, is to angle the bit a little and when drilling only go a small depth and pull the bit out. Do this several times until you get the depth you need.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Great appliance  for fertilizing trees, installing bird feeder poles and aerating the yard
customer_reviews.text: This was the most fun doing yardwork that I’ve ever had! Was able to bury 24 Jobes tree spikes in 30 minutes at a foot and a half deep without breaking a sweat or breaking a Jobe tree Spike! Great for airy aerating a patch of lawn too, if your yard needs it or you’re up for more fun
customer_reviews.author: Smart shopper 49

customer_reviews.title: Greta value
customer_reviews.text: Great value! Bored 20 holes in clay soil just fine. Since its not a full length auger you need to pull up frequently to clean the hole as you dig. Sometimes reverse is necessary to back it out it just pulls down. Recommmend corded dril with T handle. Seems sturdy.
customer_reviews.author: Andrew R.

customer_reviews.title: The auger itself works just fine. I have a bit of difficult in keeping ...
customer_reviews.text: The auger itself works just fine. I have a bit of difficult in keeping it locked onto the drill when encountering more than moderate resistance. It tends to slip in the chuck. If they had flanged the end a bit, the chuck grip would be much better. On the other hand if they had done that, there is the risk of the torque transferred back to you would make it difficult to keep your grip on the drill itself. My preference would be the latter and acknowledge that I have to be smart about how hard I try to push the drill!
customer_reviews.author: Occasional Spender

customer_reviews.title: Very Handy Tool
customer_reviews.text: The planting auger appears well made. It worked good cutting through small (1/8") tree and shrub roots, larger roots are harder to cut through. The shaft of the auger locked securely in the drill and did not slip during use.
customer_reviews.author: F. Finn Roch

customer_reviews.title: Works as intended - wish it had a hex shank.
customer_reviews.text: I have been using this with a cordless drill to make holes for fertilizer spikes. It works as intended and I have drilled 30+ plus holes throughout the yard. My only gripe is the shaft is competely round so the drill chuck doesn’t have a good “bite” on the shank. I would of preferred that it had a hex shank so the chuck could lock into the bit.
customer_reviews.author: Chunkster

customer_reviews.title: Some customization recommended.
customer_reviews.text: I struggled to keep the drill bit from spinning in place inside my drill. So, I went to the workshop and took out the grinder and made a triangular bit for my drill to bite on to. Now it works great. Have used the auger on over 200 holes and counting...
customer_reviews.author: A. Deskins

customer_reviews.title: Worked great!
customer_reviews.text: I bought this to plant 100+ bulbs in the fall and it worked great! Saved me a ton of time. My soil is sandier which helped so the auger wouldn't get stuck in the soil. The part that inserts into the drill - the coating flaked off right away, but it still worked fine.
customer_reviews.author: B.W.

customer_reviews.title: 1 3/4 was already pushing it and this misslable makes it nearly useless for me
customer_reviews.text: First off the product is 2 inch not 1 3/4 inch. I know that sounds nitpicky but for my purpose that makes it too large. 1 3/4 was already pushing it and this misslable makes it nearly useless for me. Also the material it is made from is SUPER cheap. One use and it ground down the shaft till it broke. Total and complete garbage. The end wasn't even boxed out so it could grip a drill chuck properly. It is just a shaft. I would give this item a 0 if I could but Ill settle for a 1 I guess.
customer_reviews.author: cribbs

customer_reviews.title: It works!
customer_reviews.text: When I ordered this I thought it was going to be a joke, the joke was on me....... It's awesome! I used a 12v Makita cordless drill with a mostly dead battery, I had the 10 holes drilled for my tiny trees in less than two minutes. Having dug the first 14 holes by hand, I can tell you that Southern Oklahoma dirt is still just as hard to dig in as I remembered it to be, but not for the drill. Get one, you won't be disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: Todd Barksdale

customer_reviews.title: Like others have noted
customer_reviews.text: Like others have noted, the end which goes into the drill chuck is round and slips easily. The coating also quickly wore off. The trick I found to using is to set the clutch to about 3/4ths of maximum and don't push too hard. I also had better luck after watering the ground to soften it up. I planted 180 bulbs in a couple of hours TOTAL with help from this thing. Nice.
customer_reviews.author: JD

customer_reviews.title: Cheap
customer_reviews.text: Very disappointed in this. Not a one piece design, the spiraled part is only tack-welded on in a few spots. The whole thing is made out of some cheap pit metal. Gave it two stars because it isnt made out of plastic. That's about the only way they could have made it cheaper.
customer_reviews.author: Redleg27

customer_reviews.title: I think if you wanted something to maybe plant bulbs in really loose loamy soil this would work great. Anything else harder than
customer_reviews.text: I bought this to try and get through some tough soil, It did not work for that hardly at all. I think if you wanted something to maybe plant bulbs in really loose loamy soil this would work great. Anything else harder than that probably not. I think one of the biggest issues is probably the end you stick into the drill because it is completely round and slips in the drill chuck.
customer_reviews.author: Jason

customer_reviews.title: Good Auger for bulbs
customer_reviews.text: This is a good accessory to my gardening tools. The only thing I regret is I should have gotten a wider diameter auger this one is a little small. When using go slow initially because if it hits a rock it can twist your arm pretty good depending on the power of your drill. I also use it to break up the dirt before digging a hole for plants I have found it very useful for that since I have a lot of clay in my soil.
customer_reviews.author: J. Timothy Sensor

customer_reviews.title: Recommend you use this only with a good 1/2 drive ...
customer_reviews.text: I used a drill with a 3/8 chuck and the inserted end wore off and broke. Recommend you use this only with a good 1/2 drive that uses a key so that it does not slip. Otherwise the bit itself worked ok. It works better going straight into the ground. I was trying to create a hole underneath a walkway to run a piece of water line through. I had a lot of difficulty. Even small tree roots will stop it when using a good drill.
customer_reviews.author: MM

customer_reviews.title: Nice Drill Attachment!
customer_reviews.text: It's a good attachment for your drill, I use it mostly in the garden to dig small holes quickly. But it's not very sturdy, it bent easily when I tried to dig a hole in a clay soil!
customer_reviews.author: RJ

customer_reviews.title: Doesn’t work well in heavy clay
customer_reviews.text: My compost/clay garden dirt did not let it drill well. It only drill about 2 inches deep. Unfortunately, I bought it too early and the return window closed before I could return it. Perhaps as I add amendments to my soil this auger will finally work for me,
customer_reviews.author: Picky Texan

customer_reviews.title: Works great!
customer_reviews.text: You’ll need to keep tightening into the drill but works really great. Was able to make a bunch of post holes with renting a auger saving money and time. I think it’s great for a hole here and there or a project.
customer_reviews.author: Mike

customer_reviews.title: cheap, but will do the job
customer_reviews.text: This is one of those tools you buy for a single job so you look for the best price. Mine arrived in a huge box (compared to the size of the auger) well packaged to prevent in transit damage. It's not bent, but when you put it in a drill and pull the trigger, you can see and feel that it's not straight either. Like others have said you have to grind a flat on the shaft so the drill can hold it. Even though I bought it for a single job, it doesn't seem fit for the use. I think at the price it may not be worth sending it back.
customer_reviews.author: Grant H.

customer_reviews.title: Fun Tool for quick, multiple plants
customer_reviews.text: Longer than I expected (18-inch version). Maybe I should have gotten the 9-inch. I'm worried I might puncture the utilities if I dig straight down with this guy. But it feels sturdy and durable and holds up in the soil. Will probably be in the garden chest and used regularly for years to come. Great for bulbs or annuals grown in a flat--perfect size hole and can loosen the dirt underneath to allow the roots to grow.
customer_reviews.author: Scags

customer_reviews.title: Disappointing quality, spins in chuck.
customer_reviews.text: These could have been amazing, but they were just so-so because the end that chucks into the drill is just round stock, and poorly cut. As a result of not having any hexagonal grips machined in the chuck end, the auger spins in every drill I tried. I half-way machined some flats into that with a grinder, and the auger does perform somewhat now, though the hand-cut flats made the auger out of balance. That being said, this is the only 1-1/4" auger I could find commercially available. The auger itself is a fairly thin gauge spiral, stitch-welded in 3 places. That could also be better.
customer_reviews.author: Aloysius J Moore

customer_reviews.title: A fine and handy tool
customer_reviews.text: A fine and handy tool, does what it is supposed to. If you're going deep - best to use a corded drill for higher torque. We used it to drill a hole for a weather station pole sunk 2.5' down (1st 8" was a hand dug wider hole). A few tips if you're doing something similar - 1) Pound a piece of rebar down first and then remove to give the bit an easier time and bust minor rocks; 2) Soak your hole with water, let it sit for a day and then drill - makes life much easier, especially if you're dealing with hard packed clay soil.
customer_reviews.author: Jeanne Reilly

customer_reviews.title: 500 tulip bulbs planted in 3 hours!
customer_reviews.text: Using this with a cordless drill, I put in 500 tulip bulbs in three hours. Soil varied from hard and stony to well-worked. The Roto Driller worked well in all conditions for me. The drill's battery pack lasted about 100 bulbs in the worst soil to over 150 in raised beds. Sometimes the bit would catch on stones or roots and twist out of my hand so depending on your arm and wrist strength, or lack thereof, and the drill's torque setting, your mileage may vary. Highly recommend for putting in many bulbs quickly!
customer_reviews.author: Ken Stuart

customer_reviews.title: Works For Me
customer_reviews.text: I needed to install 6 anchors to stabilize my mower canopy. The area where the canopy is located has some rather hard soil which I was unable to penetrate to a sufficient depth. This auger solved the problem. I used my power drill and was careful not to rush the job but by taking my time and sort of biting off chunks I was able to create a hole that allowed me to install the auger and still maintain stability for the canopy.
customer_reviews.author: Duffer.Top Contributor: Cooking

customer_reviews.title: It works great because I don't have to bend over to dig ...
customer_reviews.text: I've been wanting one of these for three years. They don't sell this size in the garden center or hardware stores (at least not where I am). It works great because I don't have to bend over to dig holes for bulbs. Also good for plant stakes, shepards hooks etc. We have that hard clay soil and this works great. I found out it's also good to stir the compost bin.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Not as described
customer_reviews.text: Description says 1 1/4 inch diam when this is actually 1 3/4 . Already have 2” so this is redundant . Going back . All these sales and nobody noticed error?
customer_reviews.author: D. Ryan

customer_reviews.title: Look! It's an auger.
customer_reviews.text: It's long. I can attach it to a drill. It makes holes in the ground. Pretty much what I expected. Update: The shaft does not have any flat places for the chuck to grip. I've found that when I use this, the paint peals off around the chuck and the auger spins. I found that creating some flat spots with a grind, allows the auger to grip better.
customer_reviews.author: DGBradley

customer_reviews.title: Does its job
customer_reviews.text: This digs very well, just be sure to move up and down as you go, don't just try and drill straight down. Only complaint was that it seemed to slip in my drill as the paint flakes off, but that may also be user error if I didn't get it tight enough. I used this with a dewalt battery operated drill.
customer_reviews.author: yarrumj

customer_reviews.title: Good auger with a shortcoming
customer_reviews.text: Handy little tool. I use it for fertilizer spikes now..a lot easier than hammering the in the ground. I did grind flats on the chuck-end of the shaft so the drill will get a better grip on the auger. Once I did that, the little booger will go through just about anything. Well made in Mexico.
customer_reviews.author: Nonamemarine

customer_reviews.title: Size issue
customer_reviews.text: When I ordered it was listed as a 2.6" diameter, now it's listed as a 1.25" diameter, I received a 1.75" diameter. So I guess I broke even?
customer_reviews.author: Scott

customer_reviews.title: Well made, sturdy feel.
customer_reviews.text: Feels really sturdy, I used it to auger holes in January for fertilizer spike on appletrees in partially frozen ground in mid January and it ripped right into the dirt no problem at all.
customer_reviews.author: Chad S.

customer_reviews.title: Worked great during my lawn sprinker head replacement project.
customer_reviews.text: Upon receiving this auger I clamped it into a vise, and using a flat file I filed 3 flats around the shaft, which took about 15 minutes. This was effective in preventing the auger from slipping in the drill. My main reason for purchasing this was to use in replacing a couple of dozen sprinker heads in my yard that no longer pop'ed up or retracted properly. The auger was excellent in loosening the clay soil around the sprinkler heads so I could dig down far enough to unscrew the pop-up heads. My 18V cordless drill didn't bog down, even though I was digging in heavy clay. Product worked great for this application.
customer_reviews.author: SWALKER

customer_reviews.title: Works great!
customer_reviews.text: This thing works great! I just dug a fairly wide and deep hole in my garden to set a fence post for my hose rack and a clock. With all the rain we've had recently, the ground was somewhat soft and it really cut right through the dirt and kind of pulverized it. It was easy to shovel out. I have a shoulder injury, so can't do a lot of hard digging. It was a real life saver. Highly recommend.
customer_reviews.author: John in Virginia

customer_reviews.title: Best 4 or six pack too
customer_reviews.text: Best 4 or six pack too.darn garden tool i ever bought. Not only good for bulbs, but for annuals in 4a or 6 pack too. Perfect height for me. I am 5'3" . if you are tall, you are going to be bent over. a must buy
customer_reviews.author: Rebecca Cimbat

customer_reviews.title: Fell apart.
customer_reviews.text: It is very poorly made. We used it to try to aerated the ground around a tree. The ground was moist and soft . The shaft twisted off twice and the final straw was the auger fell right off of the shaft into the hole.
customer_reviews.author: cmc

customer_reviews.title: Use Only in the Garden or Prepared Soil
customer_reviews.text: Use this under trees with a drill and the results were very unsatisfactory. The auger will do its work in prepared soil, as in a flower bed or garden, but cannot work in unprepared ground.
customer_reviews.author: D. Hartgrove

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for my small container garden!
customer_reviews.text: Used this to plant lettuces, kale, tomatoes, etc, in loose soil inside my garden container. It also worked perfectly planting the marigolds in the ground outside the box. Saved me hours. Used it with my DeWalt screw gun.
customer_reviews.author: Anonymous

customer_reviews.title: Gardening or landscaping must have
customer_reviews.text: Works great with my drill. The length keeps me from having to bend so far down during use. Would recommend for gardens or landscaping!
customer_reviews.author: Meghan

customer_reviews.title: Almost mosquito-less in Houston!
customer_reviews.text: No more standing water in the yard! Bored holes every 1 1/2' around perimeter of the houses foundation 1 1/2' away from the foundation. Filled the holes with gravel, so now I'm not having to worry about expensive future foundation repairs. It's a Houston thing if you aren't knowing what I'm talking about. Did the same for low spots in the yard that would have standing water after hard rain falls. So far so good! Anything to NOT help the mosquito population survive!
customer_reviews.author: D & R

customer_reviews.title: MUST BUY
customer_reviews.text: I should have bought one YEARS ago. This size/diameter Is perfect for drilling pocket holes for saturation watering of my fruit trees.
customer_reviews.author: KidTako

customer_reviews.title: Works Great!!
customer_reviews.text: Works great. No complaints. I use it to drill holes in the ground near my tree roots to apply fertilizer.
customer_reviews.author: Gerald

customer_reviews.title: it worked great for my needs
customer_reviews.text: As others have commented, it does come loose at times. For the money however, it worked great for my needs. 90 bulbs in under an hour. The longer one may save your back, as this one is quite short, but I saw that in the description when I purchased...Wish I got the super long one now!
customer_reviews.author: Fishing Nut

customer_reviews.title: Big time saver for planting bulbs or preparing holes prior to inserting small wooden stakes.
customer_reviews.text: If you are planting more than a few bulbs, you need this. Be careful though, if you use a high torque drill, there is a very real risk of twisting you arm if the drill engages too quickly. Depending on the soil conditions, your mileage may vary. The soil I was using this in is a clay sand mix with some highly compacted clay. I found that pulling up the auger quickly whil spinning, after achieving the desired depth, was most effective for clearing the hole of debris. Huge time saver!
customer_reviews.author: Stephen F. Abbot

customer_reviews.title: Good depending on what you are I using it for.
customer_reviews.text: I purchased to help with install of post spikes that hold a 4x4 post. Not very helpful. This would be great for bulb planting or other garden projects. I would also suggest looking for one that has a hexed end for the drill. This one has a smooth end so it will not lock in as tight limiting the density of the ground it will turn through. Get bigger than you think you need since the dirt falls in the hole as you move down. Bottom line fine for the right use.
customer_reviews.author: Rob

customer_reviews.title: Good Pproduct.
customer_reviews.text: Very good product. Tip not too penetrative but still effective. Paint coating is thick and able to withstand wear through soft soils. Drier and stony soils will cause paint finish to quickly wear away. So far used it to bore holes in ground to insert tree fertilizer pods. Plan to use it to bore under drains to install plumbing lines.
customer_reviews.author: SHAN DEV

customer_reviews.title: Lifesaver
customer_reviews.text: I wish I ordered this sooner. I had someone give me about 1200 daffodil bulbs and this was a life saver, I was digging holes with a hand scoop. This is a life saver for the smaller bulbs maybe not so much for the larger ones.
customer_reviews.author: M. Monical

customer_reviews.title: Apparent poor design negatively impacts performance
customer_reviews.text: As previous reviewers have noted, the portion of the shaft of the auger that fits into the drill chuck does not have flattened faces. Consequently, the auger slips within the drill chuck when the auger encounters moderate amount of resistance caused by compacted soil or a small rock. This is definitely a poor design. If you are going to purchase this bulb auger, I suggest that you use it in soft soil with little or no small stones.
customer_reviews.author: Jeff S

customer_reviews.title: It came, it drilled. Just as advertised
customer_reviews.text: It works, even here in Georgia USA. Arrived on time or better, tested, accepted. A bit pricey, and I would buy it again,
customer_reviews.author: Chris

customer_reviews.title: Disappointing. Drill Bit Slips.
customer_reviews.text: Makes only a shallow impression in the soil before the drill bit starts slipping in the drill. Disappointing product.
customer_reviews.author: Michiguy

customer_reviews.title: Use a corded drill!
customer_reviews.text: First off use a corded drill!!! The length is awesome I am 6 foot and barely had to bend over. We have clay soil and it worked perfectly. My husband and I planted almost 300 bulbs in less than an hour. He said, "Why did you not buy this for me before?!" We beat it up pretty good and it stood up to roots and clay. I just wish that I had ordered more bulbs.
customer_reviews.author: The Muskrat

customer_reviews.title: Worked Great!
customer_reviews.text: Did exactly what I needed it to. Moved into a new house with very hard dry dirt in the flower beds. Used this to loosen up the dirt to be able to put in some plants. Dug a bunch of holes and even got tangled up in roots a few times. The auger has held up to it all and still working perfectly.
customer_reviews.author: TJW

customer_reviews.title: works great
customer_reviews.text: This auger digs in the ground better than I anticipated. The end that goes in drill is not round as others have said but hexagonal shape to keep it from slipping. I would buy it again.
customer_reviews.author: John S.

customer_reviews.title: Works well for medium tasks
customer_reviews.text: Did what I needed it to. Its built well, but not the best. When it grabs onto a root, be ready to for a ride.
customer_reviews.author: vegas

customer_reviews.title: 400 bulbs later and ready for next season! nice product!
customer_reviews.text: This thing works great! If you prep your bed out you can plant hundreds of bulbs in an afternoon. In unprepped soil it can be a bit of a battle with rocks or roots being the major issues. This item is really nice compared to several other brands as it is one piece instead of two making it much more durable.
customer_reviews.author: BrotherQ

customer_reviews.title: Great tool for tough, dry soil.
customer_reviews.text: I recently had a piece of equiptment removed from an area in my front yard. I used this auger to place microbes in the soil after the soil looked like it was no longer healthy. This auger was the perfect tool. It drilled the crusted soil with ease and helped me get the job done in no time.
customer_reviews.author: LilAprilJewel

customer_reviews.title: Works, but quality control could be better
customer_reviews.text: It's a fair product. The 2 boxes it was shipped in were pristine. The shaft on the auger arrived bent with no damage to the boxes. With a bit of effort I think I can straighten it out, but when using it it really vibrates badly. I dug 4 holes in rocky soil and it held up fine, so that's why 3 stars.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

product_meta.title: Yard Butler Roto Earth 30” Aerating Irrigating Planting Auger Drill Bit Digs Holes For You, IRD-2
product_meta.description: Style:30-InchYard Butler Roto Digger does the work for you. Attach to any cordless drill 3/8 inch or larger and quickly dig holes up to 28 inches deep x 1 1/4 inches wide. Great for installing PVC sprinkler lines under sidewalks; deep watering, aerating and fertilizing trees and shrubs; and insecticide applications and termite treatments.
feature_bullets: GARDEN AUGER DRILL DIGS FOR YOU - This durable auger drill device does the hard gardening work for you. Attach the garden auger to any electric or cordless drill ⅜” or larger to dig holes in your garden with ease.

PERFECT FOR PLANTING BEAUTIFUL PLANTS - Perfect for planting bulbs, bedding plants, and seedlings, there is no better gardening drill bit for digging holes in your yard. This auger attachment can also help take care of those pesky weeds.

THE GARDEN YOU’VE DREAMED OF - Easily make your yard look beautiful by planting the flower bed you’ve been wanting, or a full garden that’s sure to impress. This garden auger for electric drill is exactly what you need to get started.

BUILT TO LAST - Pulverize soil and dig deep holes with this heavy duty nine inch roto drill attachment. Made from powder coated durable steel, this garden drill is 18” tall, 1 1/4” wide, and weighs 1lb.
30 DAY NO RISK GUARANTEE - Yard Butler products are equipped with a no risk 30 day satisfaction guarantee. If it’s not perfect for you, return it for a full refund.

specifications.Domestic Shipping: Item can be shipped within U.S.
specifications.International Shipping: This item can be shipped to select countries outside of the U.S. Learn More
specifications.Customer Reviews: 4.4 out of 5 stars1,210 ratings4.4 out of 5 stars
